subject: Re: [junit] Re: How does Unit test in a heirarchy works...
msgSnippet: Greetings folks, my comments inline.. ... I mentioned my design has a heirarchical structure and would like to have my tests also have a heirarchical structure
messageBody:
Greetings folks,
my comments inline..

> >> The design /is/ the point of the discussion.
> >
> > No, it is *a* point of discussion. It's healthy to ask the
> > original poster if this design is really necessary, but if
> > they say "yes", then we should just move on to solving their
> > problem and not patronize them on how pure their architecture is.
>
> You are probably more referring to my posts than to J.B.'s.
>
> If the OP said something along the lines of "I know the design is
> suboptimal, but I currently can't do something about it", I would have
> accepted that and concentrated on solving his testing problem using Junit.
>
> But I didn't understand him to say that. Instead I understood him to say
> something more along the lines of "my design is quite good the way it is,
> and it is strange that Junit doesn't support testing it very well."
>
> From the little I know about his design, I still doubt that the design is
> as
> good as it could be, and I thought it might be of value to point that out,
> and perhaps even get an interesting discussion going on that issue. If I
> sounded patronizing that way, I appologize - that wasn't my intent.

I mentioned my design has a heirarchical structure and would like to
have my tests also have a heirarchical structure for testing this
behavior easily. This would help avoid lots of redundant coding and
leads to cleaner & easy to understand implementation. I was using
jUnit (cactus based on this) but it is found to be not meant for this.

Fine, alternates like ObjectMother (which maintains heirarchical impl
and single level tests classes just use them as helpers), TestNG were
suggested which is what I expected from this thread. Also, it was
made clear that jUnit is not meant to do this, which is absolutely
fine.

Expecting OO behavior in test classes is a requirement which I see for
my design at least. I did not want to 'derail' the discussion from
testing to making design changes and thatz why I made it clear that
'letz not question the design'. Also someone was of the opinion that
deep heirarchy could be a bad design..I wanted to step-in and say 'of
course not..it has it's own reason'.

> > In real life, faulty or imperfect designs are the norm.
>
> Sure. That's one reason unit testing is so valuable: it makes some of the
> imperfectionism more visible, so that we can work on it.
'Faulty or imperfect design'- well thatz not the case when we can't
use jUnit for this purpose. May be there are other tools which meets
this need. Sometimes the app design might not provide interfaces to
such a granular level that unit test might need. It doesn't mean the
design is imperfect or sub-optimal.

> > If a framework forces you to change your design to be useful,
> > you can bet that most companies will keep their design and
> > choose another framework.
>
> And some developers would rather choose a framework that is lightweight
> than
> one that better supports scenarios they don't strive for anyway. It's nice
> that we have a choice, isn't it?
>

The intent to bring this up is to know..
1. Is this a common requirement and if yes, how is it handled?
2. If not, what is the recommended way of doing this?
3. tradeoffs, pros & cons of each of these approaches.
4. Any tools/framework which supports these.
5. Real time experience on testing some of this kind..

I wanted to provide nice examples for expressing my need with a sample
code. Also I would like to summarize things which I have got out of
this discussion. Becoz of lack of time I could not do that so far. I
will find time if someone really want to take this forward.

~JAK

~JAK
